comments.commentBody: That money should be saved for higher education, not more insane pageants

In my experience women (young or old) are sexualized whether they wear makeup or not.  To fix that you have to fix men...a prospect I would happily invest in.  Emily and young women will be viewed under a sexual lens her entire life and I for one congratulate any woman for seizing the power.  Perhaps we place too much emphasis on telling women how they should or should not look.  Fix the damn men.

I am not likely to soften my judgment of these awful events.  Those thousands of dollars should be saved for college or spent on music lessons, sports, dance -- there are many things that can help grow confidence, skill, and even win ribbons.  The sexualized, objectifying, wasteful nature of these pagents where girls are judged on their looks and bodies and fake smiles cannot be justified.  It saddens me that parents, esxpecially mothers, would promote these contests and horrifies me that adults participate in judging these children in such superficial and demeaning ways.

They have many pageants for boys. People keep saying this is sexual. They are kids and don't understand any of that. The people who watch the pageants are not people that walk off the street.  These girls wear more then your kids where on the beach. These girls are not going to school, the mall or sitting at home with makeup and hair done. This is no different then a child movie star going done up for that time frame. Emily does this only during pageant time. At no time does she think she needs that to be the beautiful and the strong young lady she is.  This is what she does for fun and to enjoy girl time.

Beauty contests for children and adolescent girls are merely G-rated child pornography and burlesque. That's my objection to them. The problem is not that they "fuel female insecurity" but that they sexualize children and children's bodies. There's a reason why our culture has traditionally frowned on young girls' wearing makeup: it is because the point of makeup is to enhance the wearer's sexual desirability. There is always a tension between adolescents who want to be grown up and their parents who want to protect them. That's usually the context in which a parent says "you're too young to be dolled up like that." Here we have the exact opposite case: parents deliberately sexualizing their children and, perhaps worse, inculcating in them the deeply perverse belief that physical appearance and conformity to culturally constructed notions of beauty (which are also usually racist) are all that matter in life.

If all that were not enough, these pageants reinforce the deeply sexist double standard in which, for girls, in contrast to boys, looks are all that matter. I note, in that regard, that there are never - at least as far as I know - beauty pageants for boys. Ever wonder why that is? Could you imagine parents primping, coiffing and dressing up their 4-, 8-, or 12-year-old boys to look like runway models so that they could parade in front of a group of grown men and women and be judged on how beautiful they are? Demeaning and distasteful, no? Thus for girls.

I agree with you completely. SoCal would never have been inhabited were it not for the water that came down to them from the Colorado River, and dams and rivers up north. It is truly a desert.

Even the Central Valley, farmed now by huge Agricultural businesses with hundreds of thousands of acres each, was a desert until Sierra snowpack and northern rivers were harnessed and dams and aqueducts built to channel all that water so that the "desert could bloom".
Maybe it's just wishful thinking on my part...but I predict that Mr. Netanyahu will not be able to form a coalition, and will not be Israel's next Prime Minister.

Myron - that's what the Israelis would like us to believe.  But I don't know -- sounds to me like US Republicans saying Obama doesn't negotiate in good faith when their idea of "negotiate" is "2 for me, none for you".
"Everyday Americans" don't even know an election in Israel took place. Or care.

'Maybe Netanyahu has been taking lessons in duplicity from his Republican pals.'

I object. To say that Netanyahu has learnt from the GOP - that is so arrogant!

It is the GOP that can learn from Netanyahu/Israel on duplicity. They are far ahead of us, by far.

Maybe Netanyahu has been taking lessons in duplicity from his Republican pals.  One of his predecessors said something on the lines that you make peace with with your adversaries, not with your friends.  He could find that, for the sake of winning dirty, he will end up having to make peace with everyday Americans who have lost patience with their former friends.

"Liberal Israel will need our support."

There is no 'liberal Israel' to speak of. Over 58% of Israeli Jews have proven to be not moderates by way of voting, forget liberal. No party in Israel ran on a platform of peace, or 2 state solution.
How can they speak out and hope to change things without a strong coalition backed by the United States?

They cannot do it by themselves, anymore than the German People could stop Nazism.  You have a nice sentiment, but the reality is you cannot stop the tide that way.  The longer this goes on unanswered, the more years and bloodshed will be required to end it.

Sandy,
This sounds all familiar although my gorgeous French mother was my personal 'weight watcher' and it was a losing proposition for me because I was small, healthy, and Nature with my medium frame and figure would have me at 5'2 at 116. Well, I started the diet game, and if I am still here it's because of my strong constitution. "Fat" to my parent's mind, an artist and an architect, was the big criminal sin of all time, and I could write a short story about it.

The corker in what you have to relay is what the salesgirl at Ohrbach's had to add, and then begins the battle of the bulge. Let us find the weight that we feel comfortable with, and start learning more about our individual metabolism, diet maintenance and good habits. In the meantime, your comment is of help to others, while keeping in mind that 'perfect' is what one suits one best.

On St. Patrick's day, a friend sent me a scientific study that women who carry some extra weight live longer than the men who mention it. To which I replied this is true and gives new meaning to 'Stout' when enjoying one at the local pub. To health in our golden years!
I had never heard of the "3 diamonds" previously, but in the photo that accompanies this article they're quite clear in the center model's legs.

The virus of mantras like "Thinner is better" Skinny Latte" and the like finds its genesis in a society that is already vulnerable to the disease of aspiring to look what mirrors both dependency and need to be noticed (think high heels with its clacking in a library or office) as well as showing 1000% more skin that the male colleague whether in a restaurant, office, or gym, and yes on side walks in attires that depict the body in most enticing-but-rearranged ways. Until we unearth why women are MORE prone to find attention only thru body, we would keep scratching the surface, and our heads.

The “thinner is better” mindset goes back decades. When I was in college in the late ‘60s, the diet goal for women my age was to achieve “the three diamonds:” spaces between the thighs, from knees to calves, and from calves to ankles. In 1970, I spent a summer on Weight Watchers, carrying my food scale in my purse, because at 5’4” and 134 lbs. I was told I was too fat. I got down to a goal of 116, and a size 5/6 (which today would be a 0). To celebrate, I treated myself to a shopping spree at Ohrbach’s on 34th St. I happened to mention to a salesgirl that I was buying new clothes because I’d lost weight, and she replied, “Keep up the good work--get down below 96 and you’ll be perfect!”

One of the reasons so many of us women today are battling REAL, health-threatening obesity into our golden years is that we never learned to be satisfied with our bodies as they were and simply maintain them--in trying to constantly lose weight, we set ourselves up for failure by ratcheting our metabolisms ever downward so that each rebound was faster and higher, and each attempt to lose harder and harder.

Amen to that kind of disclosure requirement. At least magazine ads for mascara are now disclosing what we all suspected: “results simulated with lash enhancements.” Nobody’s lashes are that long & full, no matter how much mascara.  And that’s just vanity--girls trying to emulate figures that exist only in digitally altered computer files are dieting nearly to death (and at the very least, dooming their long-term weight control efforts to failure while destroying their self-esteem). However, it’s not the industry’s fault alone. Parents have to impress on their snarky, insulting kids just how viciously wrong and destructive their online fat-shaming behavior can be.

You are proposing a solution to a hypothetical problem. What models are being forced to gain weight to get work? The limitations being proposed and discussed here are to prevent the fashion industry from forcing girls and women to diet to extreme, unhealthy levels to get work.

Wolf Hall and Bring up the Bodies-- my favorite historical fiction in years, especially Wolf Hall.
Geez-- Reread the passages that confuse you in terms of narrative or pov--
The depiction of Cromwell was so fully formed and brilliant-- I though he jumped off the page. Can't wait for the tv series ( and the last volume).. Not a hair's difference between this cast of characters and the House of Card bunch

Not liking Ms. Mantel's work has nothing to do with Philistinism.  It has to do with literary taste.  I have happily read The Tale of Genji, Tolstoy, Proust, Joyce, and Faulkner, and (no surprise) would prefer any of them over Ms. Mantel's novels.  "Wolf Hall" so infuriated me by its pretentious stylistic tics that I couldn't bear slogging through the second book.  TV strikes me as just the right medium for them.  Your letter is disgustingly contemptuous of the naysayers.

Whoa.
The first paragraph is clearly about the actors on set, and not the actual Cromwell and Henry.
Well -- it's thoroughly researched re-imagined history.

Did you not like Pigott-Smith's performance in "Jewel in the Crown"?  I thought he was wonderful.  His greatest TV performance, though, was as Angelo in the decades-old BBC version of Shakespeare's "Measure for Measure"--a subtler, tortured, and redeemable 'villain'.  His was the finest acted version of Angelo I have ever seen (and I've seen eleven productions of that play).
Picking up nuances may not work, since they may be in the sections that have been cut for American consumption.

I've been a huge Mark Rylance fan ever since seeing him as Olivia in "Twelfth Night" in 2003 (in Ann Arbor!). The production, and his performance, were so wonderful that I waited in line for about four hours to get a ticket to see it a second time. I'm happy that his career has taken off (to put it mildly) and that so many more people now get to see his work. Now I'm just hoping that a film is made of "Farinelli and the King" so I can get to see it...
His take is also obviously 25% of the Knesset ministers so not exactly overwhelming, but it was enough to prove that the Israelis could care less what "the hand that feeds them" has to say...for now.
He won a clear plurality - six seats more than his closest opponent. In Israel's system that's a very significant difference.

I understand that Israel' Parliament is famously fractious, but a "clear mandate?"
"With a commanding 30 of Parliament’s 120 seats, compared to the 24 won by his center-left opponent, Mr. Netanyahu said he would work quickly to solidify a new government."
Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but Netanyahu *still* needs to maintain 61 votes, which means that his coalition partners will actually be the larger part of the governing majority, no? I'm not sure how that adds up to a clear mandate? Is it because pollsters got it wrong leading up to the election?
What virtual tie? The moderates won 39 seats, right-wingers won 67, Arabs won 14. As far as Jewish voters, it's a landslide for right-wingers (39 vs. 67), not a "virtual tie".

FNN Elke!

I don't know why, but "Friendly Neighbor to the North" *always* makes me smile. And I just now got to wondering, did any of your grade school textbooks or teachers ever refer to the U.S. as your "Friendly Neighbor to the South"?

(It won't hurt my feelings if they didn't.)

Nope.  But they went on and on about the world's longest un-somethinged border.  Something about not (then) needing a passport.  When I was little we used to go back and forth at will, with no sort of check that I remember.  But my mother had a problem once when she was about 10 years old and still spoke with a Scottish accent.  She had gone to Canada and was coming back but didn't have any papers with her and was detained.  I don't know if her parents were citizens yet, but they had to come with some sort of proof of legal residence to reclaim this threat to the nation's integrity.

and FNN and ELfin yekKE Elke
spenyc- I first saw the " FNN " the other day (used by you) in discussion with the word "hoser". Did not go to grade school on this continent, and in middle school (Grade 7/8) was busy getting caught up on this continent's teen culture. The border must have been very friendly in the mid-50's. I don't remember having any problems going with a Toronto Model UN Assembly group to NYC and the real UN (was not yet a Canadian citizen). Keepsake of that trip- a picture of me on the ferry with the Statue of Liberty in the background. Don't ask which country my school and I represented.
No, I have not heard the term "FNSouth"- I just know they are and I hope it will always be so. As the Peace Arch at the border states: "Children of a Common Mother".

and FNN Elke
Like Mac K, I really liked this puzzle and clever theme.
When we came to this continent (as teens), we were really impressed at the display of bookshelves full of dictionaries- MANY so nice and shiny and barely used.......
Now Wikipedia is my go- to source (and, yes, I sent them a check when they asked)
Had some misses- "unnerve" before UNHINGE, "aha" before *H*. Liked clue for French HIER (rather than German "here"). Learned MET A COMET (?). Had "usage" before USERS.
BOSSA nova and I MET were givens for us oldies-thank you - as was ONE AD, even though it's before our time :))
I detect a secondary theme: The collapse of ENRON in TEXAS with its ILLICIT activities left many investors STUNG and WITH NEXT TO NOTHING and having to go BACK TO BASICS from what may have been initially a situation of RAGS to RICHES. No MADE TO MEASURE suits for them after wards.
Wonder who John will have as his avatar today- K.L.?
9:10pm Pacific Time

Experts expect Bibi to walk back his comment that there will never be a Palestinian state. I'm no expert and I will question the intelligence of anyone who believes him if he does so. The assertion that he will stop building settlements is ludicrus. Bibi wants an apartheid state until Israel can arrve at some sort of final solution for the Palestinians. The Palestinians, out of frustration, will continue to lob rockets into Israel and and the IDF will "mow the grass" in Gaza murdering civilians and making an already barely tolerable existence even worse, while cowardly American politicians purchased with Jewish lobby money, will pledge their continued support to Israel.

BUT-more and more Americans are tiring f seeing our tax dollars being used to kill children; of Israel leaders treating America as if we need them and not they who need us; of their disrespect and humiliation of our leaders. Israel make s grave mistake in assuming they can continue to behave as they have. For the first time today I went to the Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions website. I have contacted my two Senators and congressional representative, all Democrats, and told them that they will assert themselves in response to Israeli misbehavior and stop being Zionist lapdogs, or they will no longer get my vote. I haven't been this angry since Jeb Bush threw the election to his brother George.

It is a bit hard to see how Mr. Netanyahu can be set on a new track by his election win since he was renewed and supported in all his extremist beliefs and will no doubt take his electoral victory as encouragement to continue leading his country down the road to more settlements and to loss of credibility with the international community.  The Netanyahu "victory" is really a setback for Israel as he leads it farther into the wilderness of Palestinian occupation and ruthless denial of Palestinian human rights.  There is no longer any doubt of what Mr. Netanyahu's real stance on Palestinian statehood is as he let his true feelings slip out from under his usual double talk.

Management at Facebook doesnt have to do much.  Thats why there is more women in Facebook management.  85% men.  Thats actually low by the usual tech standards.  I would go to companies were the only woman was the receptionist.  When women can code well they will be hired.  You have to earn it.  Nobody is shutting women out of a market.  Also, overall in this world women are winning all the jobs today.  The major of "Women's Studies" at Universities is all but dead.  As the times wrote about last week -- its boys that are falling behind now.  Worry about the boys.  If women want jobs as programmers they need only earn the those jobs.  And if they stay out of tech its cause they are just not interested in it.  I dont see a problem.
